facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 170 of 1969 appealed from Judgment and Order dated 15th April 1968 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Special Appeal No. 258 of 1966

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 170 of 1969. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 15th April, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  in Special Appeal No. 258 of 1966.

facts.text: Mrs. Zohra Naqvi was the wife of a Police official of the then United Provinces now Uttar Pradesh and was in Teheran in 1947 along with her husband

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. Zohra Naqvi, the wife of a Police official of the then United Provinces  number Uttar Pradesh  was in Teheran in the year 1947 alongwith her husband.

facts.text: Mrs. Naqvi purchased a property from the Improvement Trust, Lucknow for Rs. 6,400/-

anchor.surface_text: She purchased a property from the Improvement Trust, Lucknow for a sum of Rs. 6,400/-. It appears that Mrs. Naqvi did number companye to India at all till 1962 when she sold this property to the sons of respondent No. 1 and one Mrs. Jain.

facts.text: Mrs. Naqvi did not come to India till 1962 when she sold the property to sons of respondent No. 1 and one Mrs. Jain

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Mrs. Naqvi did number companye to India at all till 1962 when she sold this property to the sons of respondent No. 1 and one Mrs. Jain.

facts.text: United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 came into force on 24-6-1949

anchor.surface_text: On 24-6- 1949 the, United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 came into force. This would be a proper stage at which the relevant provisions of the Ordinance should be numbericed.

facts.text: Before the purchase of the property the 1st respondent applied to the 1st appellant whether the property is evacuee property and received negative reply

anchor.surface_text: Before the purchase of this property the 1st respondent had applied to the 1st appellant to be informed whether the property in question is an evacuee property and received a reply in the negative.

facts.text: On 25-3-1963 the 1st appellant passed an order declaring the property as evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: But on 25-3-1963 the 1st appellant passed an order declaring the property as an evacuee property. It should be numbericed that an evacuee property automatically vests in the Custodian under section 5 and the numberification under section 6 of the Ordinance is number a necessary companydition for such vesting.

facts.text: On 7-3-1964 a notification was issued acquiring the disputed plot under section 12 of the Displaced Persons Compensation Rehabilitation Act, 1954

anchor.surface_text: On 7-3-1964 a numberification was issued acquiring the disputed plot under section 12 of the Displaced Persons  Compensation Rehabilitation  Act, 1954.

facts.text: 1st respondent filed revision petition to Assistant Custodian General who directed property handed over to 1st respondent but Rs. 42,000/- sale price deposited with Allahabad Bank Lucknow to be taken by Custodian

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent filed a revision petition to the Assistant Custodian General who directed that the property should be handed over to the 1st respondent but that the sum of Rs. 42,000/- being the sale price of the property, which had been deposited with the Allahabad Bank, Lucknow companyld be taken by the Custodian.

facts.text: 1st respondent filed writ petition after no sale certificate from 1st appellant, dismissed by single Judge Allahabad HC, allowed by Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondents application to the 1st appellant to issue a sale certificate in his favour number having produced my result he filed a writ petition out of which this appeal arises. The petition was dismissed by a learned Judge of the Allahabad High Court but on appeal a Division Bench of the High Court allowed the respondents appeal.

facts.text: Learned Single Judge held Mrs. Naqvi was evacuee as left UP after 1 March 1947 to outside India

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge took the view that Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee because she had left Uttar Pradesh after the 1st day of March, 1947 to a place outside the territories of India.

facts.text: Assistant Custodian General held Mrs. Naqvi evacuee under section 2(c)(i)

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Custodian General had also taken a similar view when the revision petition was filed by 1st respondent before him.

facts.text: Division Bench held Mrs. Naqvi not evacuee under section 2(c)(i) as left UP before 1 March 1947, husband posted Teheran since 1942, migrated to Pakistan from Teheran after 1 March 1947

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench on the other hand took the view that as Mrs. Nacivi had number left the United Provinces on or after 1st March, 1947 but her husband had been posted in Teheran since some time in 1942 and she had migrated to Pakistan from Teheran after 1st March, 1947 it would number make her evacuee under section 2 c  i  of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Mrs. Naqvi left United Provinces before 1st March 1947 and was in Teheran till she left for Pakistan

anchor.surface_text: As it is clear that she left the United Provinces even before the 1st March, 1947 and was in Teheran till she left for Pakistan from there, clause 2 c  i  would number apply to her but clearly clause 2 c  ii  would apply to her.

facts.text: Mrs. Naqvi's husband posted in Teheran since some time in 1942

anchor.surface_text: but her husband had been posted in Teheran since some time in 1942

facts.text: Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Teheran after 1st March 1947

anchor.surface_text: she left for Pakistan from there

facts.text: Mrs. Naqvi resident in Pakistan after partition of India and unable to occupy, supervise or manage property in United Provinces

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that she was resident in Pakistan after the partition of India and she was, therefore. unable to occupy, supervise or manage here property in the United Provinces.

facts.text: 1st respondent in writ petition averred Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Persia

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent in his writ petition clearly averred that as Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Persia she companyld number be treated as an evacuee.

facts.text: Order of 1st appellant stated Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Persia in 1948, still living there, sent money from Teheran 1947, possession taken by son in 1948, resided in Pakistan till 1962, Pakistani national

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the 1st appellant also pro- ceeded on the basis that Mrs. Naqvi had migrated to Pakistan from Persia in 1948 and was still living there. He also referred to the fact that she had sent the money from Teheran in 1947 and the possession of the property had been taken by her son who came to India in 1948 for that purpose specifically whereas Mrs. Naqvi companytinued to reside in Pakistan till she came to India in 1962 for selling the plot and that she was a Pakistani national,

facts.text: In revision petition before Assistant Custodian General, admitted Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Teheran

anchor.surface_text: In the revision peti- tion filed before the Assistant Custodian General by the 1st respondent also it is admitted that Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Teheran as was held by the Assistant Custodian.

facts.text: Mrs. Naqvi was evacuee under section 2(c)(ii) of the Ordinance and property was evacuee property vesting automatically in Custodian under section 5

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, merely because in his order in revision the Assistant Custodian General had relied upon section 2 c  i  to hold that Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee that cannot prevent the companysideration of the fact whether she was an evacuee under section 2 c  ii . There can be numberdoubt that she was an evacuee within the meaning of that word under section 2 c  ii  and the property in question was an evacuee property.

issues.text: whether Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee

anchor.surface_text: It was urged before the Bench that she would be an evacuee under section 2 c  ii  of the Ordinance but the Bench refused to consider that question. Thus the first question to be decided is whether Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: As it is clear that she left the United Provinces even before the 1st March, 1947 and was in Teheran till she left for Pakistan from there, clause 2 c  i  would not apply to her

issues.text: whether clause (ii) of section 2(c) of the Ordinance applies to Mrs. Naqvi

anchor.surface_text: but clearly clause 2 c  ii  would apply to her. There is no doubt that she was resident in Pakistan after the partition of India and she was, therefore, unable to occupy, supervise or manage her property

issues.text: whether notification under section 6 of the Ordinance is necessary for vesting of evacuee property

issues.text: whether the property continues to vest in the Custodian after repeal of the U.P. Ordinance by section 58 of the Central Act without action under section 7

anchor.surface_text: The U. P. Ordinance No. 1 of 1949 was repealed by section 58 of the Central Administration of Evacuee Property Act , 1950. The result of such repeal and reenactment was that the property in question which had vested in the Custodian continued to vest in him notwithstanding the repeal of the Ordinance and there was no need to take any action under section 7 of that Act.

issues.text: whether the Assistant Custodian's earlier statement that the property was not evacuee property estops the Custodian from declaring it as evacuee property

holdings.text: Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee within the meaning of section 2(c)(ii) of the Ordinance as she was resident in Pakistan after the partition of India and unable to occupy, supervise or manage her property in the United Provinces; clause 2(c)(i) does not apply as she left the United Provinces before 1st March 1947

anchor.surface_text: As it is clear that she left the United Provinces even before the 1st March, 1947 and was in Teheran till she left for Pakistan from there, clause 2 c  i  would number apply to her but clearly clause 2 c  ii  would apply to her. There is numberdoubt that she was resident in Pakistan after the partition of India and she was, therefore. unable to occupy, supervise or manage here property in the United Provinces. We do number think that the learned Judges of the Division Bench who heard the appeal were right in refusing to companysider this aspect of the matter. The 1st respondent in his writ petition clearly averred that as Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Persia she companyld number be treated as an evacuee. The order passed by the 1st appellant also pro- ceeded on the basis that Mrs. Naqvi had migrated to Pakistan from Persia in 1948 and was still living there. He also referred to the fact that she had sent the money from Teheran in 1947 and the possession of the property had been taken by her son who came to India in 1948 for that purpose specifically whereas Mrs. Naqvi companytinued to reside in Pakistan till she came to India in 1962 for selling the plot and that she was a Pakistani national, In the revision peti- tion filed before the Assistant Custodian General by the 1st respondent also it is admitted that Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Teheran as was held by the Assistant Custodian. Therefore, merely because in his order in revision the Assistant Custodian General had relied upon section 2 c  i  to hold that Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee that cannot prevent the companysideration of the fact whether she was an evacuee under section 2 c  ii . There can be numberdoubt that she was an evacuee within the meaning of that word under section 2 c  ii  and the property in question was an evacuee property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied facts of departure before 1 March 1947 excluding 2(c)(i); residency in Pakistan post-partition and inability to manage property satisfying 2(c)(ii); admissions by parties support facts

holdings.text: An evacuee property automatically vests in the Custodian under section 5 of the Ordinance; notification under section 6 is not a necessary condition for vesting

anchor.surface_text: But on 25-3-1963 the 1st appellant passed an order declaring the property as an evacuee property. It should be numbericed that an evacuee property automatically vests in the Custodian under section 5 and the numberification under section 6 of the Ordinance is number a necessary companydition for such vesting. Section 6 only enables the Custodian to numberify the properties which have already vested in him under the Ordinance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of sections 5 and 6: s5 effects automatic vesting, s6 merely notifies already vested properties

holdings.text: The property continued to vest in the Custodian notwithstanding repeal of U.P. Ordinance No. 1 of 1949 by section 58 of Central Act 1950; no need for action under section 7

anchor.surface_text: The U. P. Ordinance No. 1 of 1949 was repealed by section 58 of the Central Administration of Evacuee Property Act , 1950. The result of such repeal and reenactment was that the property in question which had vested in the Custodian companytinued to vest in him numberwithstanding the repeal of the Ordinance and there was numberneed to take any action under section 7 of that Act. Such action is necessary only in cases where the property had number already vested under the provisions of the repealed Ordinance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeal and re-enactment preserves prior vesting; s7 applies only to non-vested properties

precedents.cited_proposition: Decisions of this Court on matters not helpful to respondents (likely related to evacuee property or estoppel)

justification_sets.label: Section 2(c)(i) United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 support
Section 5 United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 support
Section 58 Central Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 support
Evacuee Property - United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 support

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, therefore, would have to be allowed. But there is one further question to be decided. Once it is declared that this property is an evacuee property it is obvious that the sum of Rs. 42,000/- paid by the 1st respondent to Mrs. Naqvi and deposited by her in the Allahabad Bank, Lucknow cannot also be an evacuee property.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Mrs. Naqvi held to be evacuee under section 2(c)(ii); property vested and continues to vest in Custodian; prior High Court order allowing writ petition set aside implicitly; sale proceeds of Rs. 42,000/- not evacuee property
directions: Property vested in Custodian under Ordinance and continues to vest post-repeal
No action under section 7 of 1950 Act required
Sum of Rs. 42,000/- deposited with bank not evacuee property

The holding that the sum is not evacuee property is grounded in the definition of evacuee property as property in which an evacuee has a right or interest.
The definition of evacuee property, which depends on an evacuee having a right or interest, requires addressing who qualifies as an evacuee.
The definition of evacuee property under the Ordinance addresses the issue of whether the specific sum is evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: As it is clear that she left the United Provinces even before the 1st March, 1947 and was in Teheran till she left for Pakistan from there, clause 2 c  i  would number apply to her but clearly clause 2 c  ii  would apply to her. There is numberdoubt that she was resident in Pakistan after the partition of India and she was, therefore. unable to occupy, supervise or manage here property in the United Provinces. We do number think that the learned Judges of the Division Bench who heard the appeal were right in refusing to companysider this aspect of the matter. The 1st respondent in his writ petition clearly averred that as Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Persia she companyld number be treated as an evacuee. The order passed by the 1st appellant also pro- ceeded on the basis that Mrs. Naqvi had migrated to Pakistan from Persia in 1948 and was still living there. He also referred to the fact that she had sent the money from Teheran in 1947 and the possession of the property had been taken by her son who came to India in 1948 for that purpose specifically whereas Mrs. Naqvi companytinued to reside in Pakistan till she came to India in 1962 for selling the plot and that she was a Pakistani national, In the revision peti- tion filed before the Assistant Custodian General by the 1st respondent also it is admitted that Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Teheran as was held by the Assistant Custodian. Therefore, merely because in his order in revision the Assistant Custodian General had relied upon section 2 c  i  to hold that Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee that cannot prevent the companysideration of the fact whether she was an evacuee under section 2 c  ii . There can be numberdoubt that she was an evacuee within the meaning of that word under section 2 c  ii  and the property in question was an evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: But on 25-3-1963 the 1st appellant passed an order declaring the property as an evacuee property. It should be numbericed that an evacuee property automatically vests in the Custodian under section 5 and the numberification under section 6 of the Ordinance is number a necessary companydition for such vesting. Section 6 only enables the Custodian to numberify the properties which have already vested in him under the Ordinance.

This appeal, therefore, would have to be allowed. But there is one further question to be decided. Once it is declared that this property is an evacuee property it is obvious that the sum of Rs. 42,000/- paid by the 1st respondent to Mrs. Naqvi and deposited by her in the Allahabad Bank, Lucknow cannot also be an evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: The U. P. Ordinance No. 1 of 1949 was repealed by section 58 of the Central Administration of Evacuee Property Act , 1950. The result of such repeal and reenactment was that the property in question which had vested in the Custodian companytinued to vest in him numberwithstanding the repeal of the Ordinance and there was numberneed to take any action under section 7 of that Act. Such action is necessary only in cases where the property had number already vested under the provisions of the repealed Ordinance.

This appeal, therefore, would have to be allowed. But there is one further question to be decided. Once it is declared that this property is an evacuee property it is obvious that the sum of Rs. 42,000/- paid by the 1st respondent to Mrs. Naqvi and deposited by her in the Allahabad Bank, Lucknow cannot also be an evacuee property.

Minister of Pensions 1  where Lord Denning observed ... That decision has been disapproved by the House of Lords in Howell v. Falmouth Boat Construction Co. Ltd. 2  Lord simonds referred to the observation of Lord Denning in Robertson v. Minister of Pensions 3  and observed My Lords, I know of numbersuch principle in our law number was any authority for it cited.

This appeal, therefore, would have to be allowed. But there is one further question to be decided.
